channel.title: Strategic-Execution on Hareesh Kanchanepally
channel.description: Recent content in Strategic-Execution on Hareesh Kanchanepally

item.title: Managing T/Programme Managers
item.description:
What expectations would you set to manage your team of (Technical) Programme or Project Managers effectively?

Intro - Management by Exception

Micromanagement can stifle creativity and hinder progress. On the other hand, not supporting Programme Managers in effectively executing technical programmes and projects pro-actively could result in heavy losses. Over the last decade of managing technical programmes and managers, I developed a set of expectations building on the Management by Exception (MBE) principles. Embracing this philosophy for technical programme managers (T/PgMs) can empower them with clear expectations and autonomy, intervening only when necessary. This document outlines the “absolute musts” for T/PgMs using the MBE framework, with measurable tolerances and proactive measures to guide their actions and your monitoring.

item.title: Navigating the Spectrum of Collaboration in Product Development (Building on John Cutler's Insights)
item.description: John Cutler’s insightful ideas on convergence modes (Part 1, Part 2, and Part 3) in product development especially in handling dependencies effectively, offered a helpful perspective for understanding how collaboration styles affect project outcomes. John proposes four different modes/ways of working: Fully Embedded, Collaborative, Supportive, Transactional. And suggests that, to “make dependency management easier, you should ask yourself: “What type of working model SHOULD we use for this work?”. This struck a chord with me. In the past few years, especially in 2023, I personally experimented with two modes for two different projects: one project that integrated different skillsets into a single, unified, cross-functional, and fully embedded team, and the other that relied on transactional ways of working supported by a framework of project management processes. Based on this personal experience, I asked myself a question: if you decide on a particular mode of convergence at the outset of a project, do the different phases require a dynamic shift between full immersion and focused transactional interactions?

item.title: The Art of Launching a Tech Program: My 15-Year Playbook
item.description: Fifteen years ago, a simple question from my boss ignited a flame that still burns bright: “Can you make this idea fly?” That “idea” became my first foray into the exhilarating world of technical program management (TPM), a journey that has since woven its way through over 40 tech projects and a dozen intricate, multi-team programs. From nimble startups to sprawling enterprises, I’ve learned that while contexts may differ, the bedrock of success lies in a meticulous “set-up” phase. This isn’t a rigid checklist, but rather a playbook honed through experience, designed to de-risk delivery and unlock early learning. So, gather around, fellow journeymen, and let’s delve into the secrets that unlock high-flying tech programs.

item.title: Employing System Thinking to Technical Programme Management
item.description: Embarking on the integration of WeChat Pay for our Chinese customers was not just a project; it was a riveting exploration of dependencies, interconnections, and the intricate dance of technology in a dynamic ecosystem. This journey demanded more than conventional project management—it required a masterclass in systems thinking. In this playbook, we unravel the saga and distil the lessons learned into actionable insights for fellow technology program managers.
